evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident and can be observed or measured in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew withstands potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features and characteristics relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim context.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident and can be observed or measured in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman and headset operator indicates communication breakdown
The visual stop signal method is insufficient, implying coordination issues
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew during the event
If hardware faults or environmental marking deficiencies were documented as primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 directly describe communication and coordination issues among crew during pushback, supporting the claim of communication breakdown (R2). Discriminators favor R2 over mechanical failure and marking deficiency, and distinguish it from procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting whether procedural deviations or communication failures were primary cause

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features and characteristics relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim context.

assumptions: The described communication and coordination issues are representative of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA context.
No unreported mechanical faults influenced the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviations or mechanical faults causing the event, or if communication was effective and no breakdown occurred, the conclusion would change.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, and H9 directly describe communication and coordination among crew during pushback, showing breakdowns in signaling and awareness consistent with coordination failure rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in interpreting the sufficiency of communication signals and the exact cause of the event; no direct evidence of mechanical failure or procedural deviation.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew withstands potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from the headset operator or wingman as stated in H8 implies a communication breakdown rather than procedural deviation.
The visual signaling method described is insufficient to prevent errors under the conditions described.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and timely warnings from the headset operator or wingman that should have prevented the incident, or if procedural deviations were clearly documented as primary causes.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA as per the hist_baseline_t2_interim data.

assumptions: No direct mechanical fault evidence is present in the provided history.
The continued movement beyond TRP with engine at idle does not alone confirm mechanical failure without corroborating fault data.
defeaters: If evidence showed verified fault codes, bench checks, or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure.
If there were direct indications of equipment malfunction during the pushback.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H8) indicates communication was ongoing but no warnings were given to stop the pushback, suggesting a coordination/communication breakdown rather than a mechanical/control failure (H4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t2_interim assessment.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 is the relevant environmental or marking deficiency referenced in the claim.
The inadequacy of the visual stop signal described in H8 reflects a marking or environmental deficiency rather than solely procedural failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were clear, visible, and unambiguous to all crew members during the pushback, or if procedural deviations fully explained the event without marking issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the presence and location of the TRP marking relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, and H8 indicates that the visual signals for stopping the tug were inadequate, supporting the presence of an environmental or marking deficiency during the assessment.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking visibility alone caused the event or if procedural deviations contributed significantly

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA as observed in the hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings described correspond to the key features relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_baseline_t2_interim scope
The described visual signaling method relates directly to marking adequacy
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous to all crew members
If procedural compliance or communication failures were the primary cause rather than marking deficiencies

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 describe the TRP marking and its location relative to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, confirming the environmental marking features. H8 indicates the marking and signaling method was insufficiently effective, supporting the claim that the environmental or marking deficiency aligns with key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility or crew communication was the dominant factor

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

defeaters: If evidence showed the deviation was not documented or was missing from the dataset
If the incident was caused by environmental or mechanical factors rather than procedural deviation

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_baseline_t2_interim context.

assumptions: The TRP marking and clearance as described in H7 are representative of the actual environment during the incident.
The communication and signaling issues described in H8 and H9 directly impact the robustness of environmental/marking deficiency identification.
defeaters: If additional evidence showed clear, unambiguous marking visibility and effective communication signals that were acknowledged by all crew, this would reduce the claim's strength.
If the tug driver or headset operator had received and acted on timely warnings preventing the collision, the robustness of the environmental/marking deficiency identification would be questioned.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the TRP marking and clearance, while H8 and H9 indicate communication and signaling deficiencies that challenge the robustness of environmental/marking identification against defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness and signaling adequacy

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features and characteristics defined for the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The procedural deviation is defined by the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier.
Communication signals described are standard procedural elements for pushback.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given but the deviation still occurred, it might favor communication breakdown.
If environmental or mechanical factors were shown to cause the deviation, it would change the conclusion.

children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication system performance data and channel usage statistics during the incident timeframe

children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew positioning and movement logs or testimonies to determine if physical separation hindered communication

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are present at the location

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are visible and legible under operational conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess the visibility and legibility of markings during typical operational lighting and weather conditions

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine the condition of markings for wear, damage, or obstruction by objects or environmental factors

node.statement: Crew members were physically separated in a way that prevented direct communication

assumptions: Physical separation of headset operator and wingman from tug driver implies prevention of direct communication.
defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were co-located or had effective direct communication methods preventing breakdown.

The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 show crew members were physically separated (headset operator walking outside, wingman ahead of tug) preventing direct communication, supported by H8 indicating visual signals were insufficient and no warnings were received.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether physical separation fully prevented all direct communication.

node.statement: Environmental markings are visible and legible under operational conditions

defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP or other markings were obscured, damaged, or illegible under operational conditions, this would change the assessment.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items directly addresses the visibility or legibility of environmental markings under operational conditions.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: Required environmental markings are present at the location

assumptions: TRP ground markings are considered required environmental markings for the location.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were missing or obscured, or if the pushback procedural deviation was clearly documented as the cause.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 show the aircraft passed the required TRP markings and hit the blast barrier, indicating markings were present but not adequately heeded. H8 and H9 indicate procedural and communication issues rather than marking absence, favoring environmental marking deficiency over procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility or procedural compliance was primary cause

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust and resistant to common defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim context.

assumptions: The procedural deviation is identified primarily through crew communication and actions as described.
No significant mechanical or environmental factors contributed to the deviation in this context.
defeaters: If evidence showed that communication failures or environmental factors were the primary cause rather than procedural deviation, this would change the assessment.
If the visual signals or communication methods were proven insufficient to detect or prevent deviation, robustness would be questioned.

No reported equipment faults or environmental deficiencies imply equipment was available and functional

If communication breakdown was documented as the primary cause

node.statement: Communication channels were congested or unavailable preventing timely message exchange

assumptions: The lack of warning from wingman or headset operator implies communication channel issues or failures.
Visual signals are considered part of communication channels relevant to timely message exchange.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and warnings were given and received effectively, this would change the assessment.
If hardware or procedural deviations were proven to be the primary cause rather than communication issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, and H9 show crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation, supporting the claim that crew availability was not lacking.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4, H8, and H9 directly describe trained personnel involved in the pushback procedure, their actions, and awareness of the TRP, supporting availability of trained personnel familiar with the procedure. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over environmental, communication, or mechanical causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence clearly supports trained personnel availability
